root.title: RFC-0031: CAC RFC Document Format + Requirements Spine Governance

children.title: 0. Scope and non-goals
children.body:
This RFC defines the **single canonical representation** for APM2 RFCs and the **formal requirements schema**
used inside those RFCs.

It exists to eliminate planning ambiguity caused by multiple partially-overlapping RFC formats (YAML frames, PRD bindings,
ad-hoc Markdown), and to make RFCs mechanically lintable, hashable, and linkable.

Non-goals:

* Re-specify the entire APM2 system (that is done by the living system RFCs enumerated in §4).
* Preserve backwards-compatibility with legacy RFC templates beyond an explicit, bounded migration window.

children.title: 1. RFC document model
children.body:
An RFC is a single JSON document conforming to the `cac.rfc_doc.v1` envelope.
The document is a tree of typed nodes. Nodes are **content** (sections, definitions) or **control** (requirements, plans, tasks, decisions).

### 1.1 Normative node types (v1)

* `rfc` — root node; contains RFC title and children.
* `section` — hierarchical narrative / definitions / explanatory text.
* `requirement` — a normative requirement with testable acceptance criteria.
* `decision` — an explicit architectural decision record (ADR-like).
* `plan` — an ordered, phase-labeled migration or implementation plan.
* `task` — an atomic engineering work item, optionally bound to a ticket.

The **requirements schema** is defined in §2 and is the only acceptable representation for normative requirements going forward.

children.title: 2. Requirements schema

data.statement: Every RFC MUST be represented by exactly one canonical JSON file (no PRD bindings, no multi-file YAML frames). All normative requirements for that RFC MUST be contained in that file.
acceptance: Repository layout contains `documents/rfcs/<RFC-ID>/<RFC-ID>.cac.rfc_doc.v1.json` for each LIVING RFC.
No other file within the RFC directory is required to interpret normative requirements (ancillary files are non-normative references only).
CI lint fails if an RFC directory contains legacy template frames (`00_meta.yaml`, `01_problem_and_imports.yaml`, etc.) in lifecycle:LIVING.
data.rationale: Multi-file RFCs create split-brain truth and make review coverage impossible to audit mechanically.
edge_cases: If a legacy RFC still exists for historical context, it MUST be marked `HISTORICAL` and must not be referenced as normative.
If multiple JSON files exist for a single RFC ID, CI MUST fail with a deterministic error naming all colliding files.
data.fail_closed: Treat multiple sources of truth as an integrity violation; abort tooling (compile/lint/admission) rather than guessing.

children.title: Fail-closed schema validation for RFC documents

data.statement: Tooling that consumes RFC documents MUST validate them against the active `cac.rfc_doc.v1` JSON Schema, rejecting unknown node types and invalid fields with fail-closed behavior.
acceptance: A `cac.rfc_doc.v1` JSON Schema exists in the bootstrap bundle and is pinned by content hash.
Parsing fails if `schema` or `schema_version` is unknown, mismatched, or missing.
Parsing fails if any node has an unknown `type` or lacks required fields (`title`, `children`, etc.).
data.rationale: RFCs are normative control artifacts; permissive parsing creates silent contract drift.
edge_cases: If a document has a future `schema_version`, tooling MUST refuse to interpret it unless explicitly upgraded.
If a document mixes node versions (e.g., embeds v2 node fields), tooling MUST fail rather than partially interpret.
data.fail_closed: Refuse to execute any action derived from an unvalidated RFC document.

data.statement: Every `requirement` node MUST include a structured payload with: `level`, `statement`, and `acceptance` (non-empty list). It MUST additionally support (and SHOULD populate) `domain`, `scope`, `depends_on`, `edge_cases`, `fail_closed`, `falsification`, `evidence`, `code_refs`, and `theory_refs`.
acceptance: A JSON Schema exists for requirement nodes (`cac.requirement.v1`) and is referenced by the RFC doc schema.
CI lint fails if a requirement omits `statement` or provides an empty `acceptance` list.
CI lint warns (or fails at higher strictness tiers) if `edge_cases` is missing for security- or authority-relevant requirements.
data.rationale: A requirement without testability and explicit failure posture is not a specification; it is prose.

data.statement: Requirement IDs MUST be globally unique and stable across edits. The canonical format is `<RFC-ID>::REQ-<4-digit>` (e.g., `RFC-0020::REQ-0042`).
acceptance: CI lint rejects duplicate requirement IDs within an RFC.
CI lint rejects requirement IDs that do not match the canonical regex `^RFC-[0-9]{4}::REQ-[0-9]{4}$`.
Cross-RFC links reference requirements by full ID string.
data.rationale: Stable IDs enable traceability, dependency graphs, and gate receipts that cite requirements unambiguously.

data.statement: RFCs MUST NOT bind to PRDs as required inputs. Any prior PRD binding MUST be removed or reduced to non-normative references.
acceptance: RFC JSON documents contain no `binds_to_prd` block.
CI lint fails if an RFC directory contains a `prd_base_path` reference as a required field.
If a PRD is referenced, it MUST appear only as a `relationship` of kind `REFERENCES` with a note clarifying it is non-normative.
data.rationale: PRDs and RFCs evolve at different tempos; coupling them reintroduces split-brain truth.

children.title: In-place evolution; no dual implementations or adapter shims

data.statement: When an RFC changes an implementation-critical invariant, the system MUST migrate **in place**: no long-lived dual implementations, no legacy adapters/shims, and no indefinite bridge windows.
acceptance: Each RFC that introduces a breaking internal change includes an explicit migration cutover point and a delete-list for deprecated code paths.
If a temporary bridge is unavoidable, it MUST be time- and condition-bounded, with a hard fail-closed guard once cutover completes.
CI lint rejects RFC plans that introduce 'permanent compatibility layers' without an explicit deletion milestone.
data.rationale: Dual paths accumulate silent divergence and create policy bypass surfaces.
edge_cases: Test-only alternate implementations (e.g., in-memory stores) are permitted when they do not create a production dual-truth plane.
Bridge code MAY exist only if guarded such that ambiguous states fail closed (e.g., ledger read-mode ambiguity rejection).
data.fail_closed: If the system detects ambiguous dual-plane state at runtime, it MUST refuse to proceed rather than guess.

data.statement: When an RFC becomes obsolete, it MUST be explicitly marked as superseded, and a single replacement RFC MUST be named as the new authority.
acceptance: The superseded RFC includes a `relationships` entry of kind `SUPERSEDED_BY` pointing to the replacement RFC stable_id.
The replacing RFC includes a reciprocal `relationships` entry of kind `SUPERSEDES` listing the deprecated RFC IDs/paths.
CI lint fails if an RFC in `lifecycle:DEPRECATED` status lacks an explicit replacement pointer.
data.rationale: This eliminates contradictory RFC interpretation during planning.

data.statement: The APM2 system MUST define a minimal set of **lifecycle:LIVING** RFCs that collectively specify all kernel-authoritative behavior. All other RFCs MUST be `HISTORICAL` or `DEPRECATED` and MUST NOT be used as planning inputs except via the supersedence graph.
acceptance: The living RFC set is enumerated in §4 and is machine-checkable (list of RFC IDs).
CI lint fails if a non-spine RFC is marked `lifecycle:LIVING` without an explicit justification and an update to the spine list.
New planning or implementation tickets must cite requirements from the spine RFCs (by requirement ID).
data.rationale: A bounded spine prevents the '32 RFCs, half outdated' planning failure mode.

children.title: RFC lints are treated as admission gates

data.statement: RFC document validation and linting MUST be an admission gate for any change that modifies normative behavior.
acceptance: CI includes an RFC lint step that fails on schema violations and spine-invariant violations.
FAC gate receipts include RFC lint pass/fail status for changes that touch `documents/rfcs/**` or schema bundles.
Lint output is deterministic and includes stable defect IDs for each violated rule.
data.rationale: If RFCs are normative, they must be enforced with the same rigor as code quality and security gates.

children.title: RFC documents are content-addressable and reproducible

data.statement: RFC documents MUST be canonicalizable to deterministic bytes for hashing, signing, and evidence.
acceptance: A canonicalizer is defined for `cac.rfc_doc.v1` (ordering, whitespace, numeric/string normalization rules).
Repeated canonicalization of a valid RFC document yields byte-identical output.
Canonical bytes are hashed using a domain-separated hash function (BLAKE3) and can be stored in CAS.
data.rationale: Deterministic hashing enables provenance receipts and prevents 'same meaning, different bytes' drift.

children.body:
The requirements schema is designed to be **mechanically verifiable**, **linkable**, and **gateable**.
Requirements are not prose bullets; they are structured objects with explicit failure posture.

The normative requirements for the RFC system itself are below.

children.title: 3. RFC lifecycle and authority
RFC status lifecycle is finite-state and monotone

data.statement: RFCs MUST follow a monotone lifecycle: `DRAFT -> PROPOSED -> APPROVED -> LIVING -> (DEPRECATED -> HISTORICAL)` with no backward transitions. Lifecycle state MUST be encoded as exactly one label of the form `lifecycle:<STATE>` where STATE is one of {DRAFT, PROPOSED, APPROVED, LIVING, DEPRECATED, HISTORICAL}.
acceptance: Each RFC document includes exactly one lifecycle label `lifecycle:<STATE>` with STATE in {DRAFT, PROPOSED, APPROVED, LIVING, DEPRECATED, HISTORICAL}.
CI lint rejects illegal lifecycle transitions (e.g., lifecycle:HISTORICAL -> lifecycle:LIVING) unless accompanied by a new RFC ID and explicit supersedence mapping.
Tooling treats only lifecycle:LIVING RFCs as normative inputs for planning gates.
data.rationale: Monotone status prevents authority oscillation and ensures deprecation is explicit.

data.statement: Each RFC MUST have a `meta.stable_id` that never changes for the lifetime of the RFC ID. Renumbering or splitting RFCs MUST be done by creating new RFC IDs with explicit supersedence mapping.
acceptance: `meta.stable_id` uses the format `dcp://apm2.dev/rfc/<RFC-ID>`.
CI lint fails if `stable_id` changes for an existing RFC ID (detected via baseline snapshot).
Supersedence entries link by stable_id, not by relative file path.

children.title: Normative requirements must be implementable or explicitly unimplemented

data.statement: Each requirement SHOULD either reference its current implementation surface (`code_refs`) or explicitly declare itself unimplemented and include a plan section describing how it will be implemented.
acceptance: CI lint warns if a MUST-level requirement lacks any `code_refs` and lacks an 'unimplemented' marker.
At least one acceptance criterion for each requirement is mapped to a test, gate, or deterministic inspection procedure.
data.rationale: Prevents requirements from becoming unowned aspirational text.

children.body: The RFC system must encode authority explicitly: what is current truth, what is historical background, and how transitions occur.

The **canonical living RFC spine** is the minimal set of RFCs that jointly specify system behavior:

1. **RFC-0031** — RFC document model + requirements schema + spine governance (this RFC).
2. **RFC-0011** — Context-as-Code (CAC) substrate: canonicalization, schema admission, patch/admission, context packs, ArtifactFetch.
3. **RFC-0016** — Holonic Time Fabric (HTF): monotone ticks, HLC bounds, time envelopes, lease/time authority rules.
4. **RFC-0020** — Holonic Substrate Interface (HSI): protocol handshake, contract manifest, route semantics, receipts, session auth.
5. **RFC-0033** — Ledger + CAS + daemon persistence contract: append-only ledger, hash chaining, durable CAS, migration guards.
6. **RFC-0032** — Kernel-Native Forge Admission Cycle (FAC) vNext: work lifecycle, gates/receipts, evidence, merge/projection, quarantine.

All other RFCs are **non-authoritative historical artifacts** unless explicitly referenced by the spine RFCs as background.

children.title: 5. Tooling and enforcement
RFC lint tool provides deterministic defect IDs

data.statement: RFC lint output MUST be deterministic and MUST assign stable defect identifiers for each violated rule, so that FAC receipts and regressions can be tracked over time.
acceptance: Lint emits machine-readable JSON output with defect_id, severity, location (RFC id + JSON pointer), and message.
The same input repository state yields byte-identical lint output.
Defect IDs are stable across runs and do not depend on filesystem traversal order.

children.title: RFC tools are hermetic with respect to external state

data.statement: RFC compilation/linting MUST be hermetic: it MUST NOT depend on network access, wall-clock time, or non-reproducible environment state.
acceptance: RFC lint/compile runs in CI without network access.
Outputs do not embed wall-clock timestamps (unless explicitly marked as non-normative provenance notes).
All schema inputs are loaded from the pinned bootstrap bundle or from repository paths referenced by stable IDs.

children.body: RFCs are only useful if enforced. This section specifies the minimum tooling invariants required for RFCs to be treated as system control artifacts.

children.title: 6. Migration and archival policy
children.body:
Legacy RFC directories using the YAML frame template (`00_meta.yaml`, `01_problem_and_imports.yaml`, etc.) are permitted only as HISTORICAL artifacts.
The migration policy is:

* Convert each spine RFC to a single-file `cac.rfc_doc.v1` JSON document.
* Add explicit supersedence relationships for every RFC removed from the spine.
* Delete (or archive under a non-normative path) legacy templates after cutover; do not keep parallel truth.

This RFC does not prescribe the sequencing for system migrations; each system RFC includes its own migration plan.
